Content: The lychee is one of the four traditional southern Chinese fruits.
The longan is one of the four traditional southern Chinese fruits.
The pineapple is one of the four traditional southern Chinese fruits.
The banana is one of the four traditional southern Chinese fruits.
Colobanthus quitensis, also known as the Antarctic pearlwort, is one of two native flowering plants found in the Antarctic region.
Colobanthus quitensis has small, bright yellow blossoms.
Colobanthus quitensis is about 5 cm (2 inches) tall, close to the ground.
Colobanthus quitensis forms dense, cushion-like clumps.
Colobanthus quitensis has a soft, moss-like appearance.
Colobanthus quitensis is a flowering angiosperm with visible blooms.
Colobanthus quitensis is a vascular plant with tiny stems and structure.
Colobanthus quitensis grows in an Antarctic habitat with rocks, snow, or ice nearby.
Colobanthus quitensis
Skeleton Flower grows up to 0.4 m (1.3 ft) tall.
Skeleton Flower has white flowers, pedicellate, with six obovate petals.
Skeleton Flower has terete stems, 30–60 cm (12–24 in) long.
Skeleton Flower has stout, knotty rhizomes.
Skeleton Flower has petals that become transparent when in contact with water.
Skeleton Flower
The provincial flower of Jilin is Clivia miniata.
Clivia miniata has long, arching, strap-like leaves about 45 cm, arranged in two rows.
Clivia miniata produces an umbel of funnel-shaped flowers.
Clivia miniata has flowers in red, orange, or yellow.
Clivia miniata produces bright-red round berries up to 5 cm.
Clivia miniata has fruits with one to a few seeds.
Clivia miniata
The provincial flower of  Hebei is Philadelphus pekinensis.
Philadelphus pekinensis is a compact, multi-stemmed shrub, about 4–6 feet tall and wide.
Philadelphus pekinensis has creamy white, disc-shaped flowers with a pale yellow tint.
Philadelphus pekinensis has flowers about 1 inch wide, growing in clusters of 3–9.
Philadelphus pekinensis has flowers resembling orange blossoms.
Philadelphus pekinensis has green, ovate to lance-shaped leaves, 2–4 inches long, with serrated edges and smooth undersides.
Philadelphus pekinensis has dark brown bark that peels with age.
Philadelphus pekinensis
The provincial flower of  Yunnan is Camellia japonica.
Camellia japonica has branches that are purplish brown.
Camellia japonica has dark green leaf tops and paler undersides.
Camellia japonica has leaves with finely toothed margins and pointed tips.
Camellia japonica has wild flowers with six or seven rose or white petals.
Camellia japonica

The proverb “南橘北枳” means that the same orange tree planted in the South bears sweet oranges, but when planted in the North produces bitter trifoliate oranges, showing how environment changes the outcome.
The orange trees in the South grow beside green hills.
The orange trees in the South grow in fertile soil.
The orange trees in the South bear round golden fruits.
The orange trees in the South have lush green leaves.
The orange trees in the North grow in hard soil.
The orange trees in the North appear stunted and thorny.
The orange trees in the North bear small bitter fruits.
The orange trees in the North have sparse leaves.
orange of the south
orange of the north
The evolution of corn has four key stages: 1.teosinte, 2. early domesticated maize, 3.developing maize, 4.modern maize.
Teosinte is a tall grass with many side branches.
Teosinte ears are very small with only a few spikelets.
Teosinte kernels are tiny and enclosed in hard fruitcases.
Teosinte kernels fall apart from the ear when mature.
Early maize has fewer branches with a thicker main stalk.
Early maize ears are larger than teosinte ears.
Early maize kernels are more numerous.
Early maize kernels are slightly larger than teosinte kernels.
Early maize kernels have thinner coverings than teosinte kernels.
Developing maize has a single strong stalk with minimal branching.
Developing maize ears are long with many kernels arranged in rows.
Developing maize kernels remain attached to the cob.
Modern maize has a tall single stalk.
Modern maize ears are large with hundreds of kernels in neat rows.
Modern maize kernels are big and naked without coverings.
Modern maize kernels are tightly attached to the cob.
Teosinte plants
maize  kernels
Teosinte kernels
Modern maize
Crotalaria cunninghamii is a perennial shrub that grows 1–3 m tall.
Crotalaria cunninghamii has hairy or woolly branches.
Crotalaria cunninghamii has dull green foliage.
Crotalaria cunninghamii has oval leaves about 30 mm long.
Crotalaria cunninghamii has large yellowish-green pea-like flowers streaked with dark purple to black lines.
Crotalaria cunninghamii has flowers growing on long spikes at the ends of branches.
Crotalaria cunninghamii has flowers that resemble a bird attached by its beak to the stalk.
Crotalaria cunninghamii has club-shaped green pods covered with soft velvety hairs.
Crotalaria cunninghamii
Mentzelia involucrata grows in rocky or sandy open places with shrubs.
Mentzelia involucrata has basal rosette leaves.
Mentzelia involucrata has toothed leaves 2–18 cm long.
Mentzelia involucrata has sessile lanceolate to elliptic leaves.
Mentzelia involucrata has five sepals 7–23 mm long.
Mentzelia involucrata has five cream-yellow petals 13–62 mm long.
Mentzelia involucrata has white bracts with green borders.
Mentzelia involucrata
The bamboo shoot emerges from the soil in spring.
The bamboo shoot has a pointed tip and reddish-brown sheath.
The bamboo shoot elongates rapidly into a tall straight stalk.
The bamboo stalk matures into a strong hollow culm with green segments.
The bamboo stalk shows green leaves at the upper nodes.
The bamboo leaves are long, narrow, and lanceolate in shape.
Bamboo shoot
Bamboo Leaves
New bamboo shoots emerge
LATE 1ST SPRING(Bamboo)
After the 60 day growth period(Bamboo)
Hydrangea macrophylla is a deciduous shrub.
Hydrangea macrophylla in acidic soil below pH 5.5 shows blue mophead flowers.
Hydrangea macrophylla in soil between pH 5.5 and 6.0 shows purple mophead flowers.
Hydrangea macrophylla in neutral to alkaline soil above pH 6.0 shows pink mophead flowers.
Hydrangea macrophylla leaves are simple, orbicular to elliptic, and acuminate at the tip.
Hydrangea macrophylla leaves have serrated edges.
Hydrangea macrophylla shrubs have opposite green leaves up to 15 cm long.
Hydrangea macrophylla flowerheads form large round clusters.
Hydrangea Macrophylla Pink
Hydrangea macrophylla Purple
Hydrangea macrophylla Blue
In the dry state, Selaginella lepidophylla curls inward into a compact dry ball.
In the dry state, Selaginella lepidophylla shows leaves that range from dark brown to light brown or reddish brown.
In the dry state, Selaginella lepidophylla appears dry and brittle on the ground.
In the hydrated state, Selaginella lepidophylla opens outward into a spreading green mat.
In the hydrated state, Selaginella lepidophylla shows delicate fern-like stems and leaves.
In the hydrated state, Selaginella lepidophylla displays green leafy fronds after rehydration.
In the hydrated state, Selaginella lepidophylla shows a low, spreading growth pattern.
Dried and curled up
Selaginella lepidophylla in the hydrated state
Selaginella lepidophylla in Dry and Hydrated States
The shaded environment shows weak light and dim surroundings.
In the shaded environment, the etiolated plant shows long pale stems stretching toward the light.
In the shaded environment, the etiolated plant shows small yellowish leaves.
The sunny environment shows bright natural light and open space.
In the sunny environment, the recovered plant shows thicker stems under sunlight.
In the sunny environment, the recovered plant shows green healthy leaves under sunlight.

There are six stages in the growth process of the strangler fig: Stage 1 – Seed Dispersal and Germination, Stage 2 – Root Development and Descent, Stage 3 – Envelopment of the Host, Stage 4 – Competition and Canopy Dominance, Stage 5 – The Host’s Demise, and Stage 6 – Final Stage.
Stage 1 – Seed Dispersal and Germination is when birds and flying foxes drop strangler fig seeds onto the high branches of host trees.
Stage 1 – Seed Dispersal and Germination is when strangler fig seeds germinate in the canopy of a host tree.
Stage 1 – Seed Dispersal and Germination is when a young strangler fig seedling grows in a dark and moist branch crevice high above the ground.
Stage 2 – Root Development and Descent is when strangler fig roots and aerial roots grow downward like long, thin threads toward the forest floor.
Stage 2 – Root Development and Descent is when strangler fig roots reach the ground and anchor the plant firmly.
Stage 2 – Root Development and Descent is when strangler fig roots thicken after reaching the ground.
Stage 3 – Envelopment of the Host is when strangler fig roots spread around the trunk of the host tree.
Stage 3 – Envelopment of the Host is when strangler fig roots fuse together to form a lattice-like woody structure.
Stage 3 – Envelopment of the Host is when the lattice of strangler fig roots encages the host tree’s trunk.
Stage 4 – Competition and Canopy Dominance is when the crown of the strangler fig expands above the host tree.
Stage 4 – Competition and Canopy Dominance is when the leaves of the strangler fig shade the host tree’s crown.
Stage 5 – The Host’s Demise is when the tightening roots of the strangler fig constrict the host tree’s trunk.
Stage 5 – The Host’s Demise is when the host tree becomes weakened inside the grip of the strangler fig.
Stage 5 – The Host’s Demise is when the host tree eventually dies while enclosed by the strangler fig.
Stage 6 – Final Stage is when the host tree decomposes inside the strangler fig.
Stage 6 – Final Stage is when the strangler fig is left as a free-standing tree.
Stage 6 – Final Stage is when the trunk of the strangler fig becomes hollow after the host decomposes.
Stage 1: Kalanchoe daigremontiana grows tiny plantlets along the edges of its fleshy green leaves, often purple-tinged on the underside.
Stage 2: Kalanchoe daigremontiana lets the plantlets detach and fall to the ground, where they quickly take root and form new seedlings.
Stage 3: Kalanchoe daigremontiana develops a tall central stalk with opposite fleshy leaves—green on top and blotched purple underneath.
Stage 4a: Kalanchoe daigremontiana grows large upper leaves that make the stalk bend downward under their weight.
Stage 4b: Kalanchoe daigremontiana produces lateral roots from the bent stalk into the soil for stability and nourishment.
Stage 5: Kalanchoe daigremontiana sends up new vertical shoots from the bent stalk, forming a cluster of plants.
Stage 6: Kalanchoe daigremontiana occasionally blooms with an umbrella-like terminal inflorescence, bearing small grayish-pink, bell-shaped flowers.
Kalanchoe daigremontian
There are three kinds of aloe that are both edible and medicinal, namely Aloe barbadensis (Aloe vera), Aloe ferox, and Aloe arborescens.
Aloe vera is a stemless or very short-stemmed plant.
Aloe vera grows 60–100 centimetres (24–39 inches) tall.
Aloe vera leaves are thick and fleshy.
Aloe vera leaves are green to grey-green in color.
Aloe vera leaves have serrated margins with small white teeth.
Aloe vera flowers are yellow.
Aloe vera flowers are pendulous.
Aloe vera flowers are tubular and 2–3 cm long.
Aloe ferox is a tall, single-stemmed aloe.
Aloe ferox grows up to 3 metres (10 feet) in height.
Aloe ferox leaves are thick and fleshy.
Aloe ferox leaves are arranged in rosettes.
Aloe ferox leaves have reddish-brown spines on the margins.
Aloe ferox flowers are bright orange or red.
Aloe ferox flowers stand 2–4 feet above the leaves.
Aloe ferox inflorescences are erect and multi-branched.
Aloe ferox inflorescences are candelabra-like.
Aloe ferox racemes are dense, cylindrical, and symmetrical.
Aloe ferox flowers are tubular and un-curved.
Aloe ferox flowers have brown tips on the inner segments.
Aloe arborescens is a large, multi-headed succulent.
Aloe arborescens is sprawling in growth habit.
Aloe arborescens typically grows 2–3 metres (6.6–9.8 ft) high.
Aloe arborescens leaves are succulent.
Aloe arborescens leaves are green with a slight blue tint.
Aloe arborescens leaves have small spikes along the edges.
Aloe arborescens leaves are arranged in rosettes at the ends of branches.
Aloe arborescens racemes are unbranched.
Aloe arborescens racemes can sprout two to several from each rosette.
Aloe arborescens flowers are cylindrical.
Aloe arborescens flowers are vibrant red-orange.
Aloe vera
Aloe arborescens
Aloe ferox
Cactus Thiemann is one of North Africa’s largest cactus farms.
Cactus Thiemann has over 150 varieties of cacti.
Cactus Thiemann has wide fields of prickly pear.
Cactus Thiemann has the largest cactus that is 8 meters high.
Cactus Thiemann has the largest cactus that is 80 years old.
Cactus Thiemann has Neocardenasia herzogiana as a tall multi-branched columnar cactus.
Cactus Thiemann has Trichocereus pasacana as a massive columnar cactus with dense spines.
Cactus Thiemann has Opuntia pilifera with pads covered in white hair-like spines.
Cactus Thiemann has Opuntia quimilo as a giant prickly pear with thick pads.
Cactus Thiemann mainly features vast fields dominated by giant columnar cacti towering across the landscape
Cactus Thiemann
Neocardenasia herzogiana
Trichocereus pasacana
Opuntia pilifera
Diphylleia grayi is a species of perennial plant in the family Berberidaceae.
Diphylleia grayi grows up to 0.4 m (1.3 ft) tall.
Diphylleia grayi has white flowers, pedicellate, with six obovate petals.
Diphylleia grayi has terete stems, 30–60 cm (12–24 in) long.
Diphylleia grayi has stout, knotty rhizomes.
Diphylleia grayi has petals that become transparent when in contact with water.
Diphylleia grayi
Dracaena cinnabari, the Socotra dragon tree or dragon blood tree,  is named after the blood-like color of the red sap that the trees produce.
The dragon blood tree has a dense umbrella-shaped crown.
Its long stiff green leaves grow in rosettes at the tips of branches.
The trunk is thick and stout with rough surface.
The branches divide repeatedly into two through dichotomous branching.
Red resin known as dragon’s blood flows from wounds on the trunk and branches.
Dracaena cinnabari
Cipocereus bradei grows with branched shoots that reach up to 3.5 meters in height and 8 to 9 centimeters in diameter.
Cipocereus bradei shoots are initially blue and later turn greyish blue.
Cipocereus bradei has 8 to 9 slightly arched ribs that are about 1 centimeter high and up to 2.5 centimeters wide.
Cipocereus bradei ribs are sharply furrowed between oval, almost bald areoles.
Cipocereus bradei thorns are variable and often completely absent on older shoots.
Cipocereus bradei central spines number 1 to 2, are black, point upwards or downwards, and reach up to 3.5 centimeters in length.
Cipocereus bradei radial spines number 4 to 5, are brownish, and reach up to 1.5 centimeters in length.
Cipocereus bradei has tubular flowers up to 7.5 cm long.
Cipocereus bradei pericarp and flower tube are frosted blue.
Cipocereus bradei flowers have outer narrow petals and inner petals that spread into a star shape.
Cipocereus bradei flowers grow on the upper stems near the ribs.
Cipocereus bradei
Cipocereus bradei flowers
The titan arum has a gigantic inflorescence when blooming.
The inflorescence of the titan arum consists of a tall central spadix surrounded by a large spathe.
The spathe of the titan arum is deep green with cream-colored specks on the outside.
The spathe of the titan arum is dark burgundy red with ribbed, frilled edges on the inside.
The spadix of the titan arum bears a ring of small cream-colored male flowers near its base.
The spadix of the titan arum bears a lower ring of pink female flowers beneath the male flowers.
The flower of the titan arum lasts only 24 to 36 hours.
The titan arum emits a powerful scent of rotting flesh during bloom.
The spadix of the titan arum heats up to human body temperature during bloom.
The odor of the titan arum is visualized as visible waves in the air.
The female flowers of the titan arum open first, and the male flowers open about a day later, preventing self-pollination.
Carrion beetles gather around the titan arum bloom.
Flesh flies hover near the titan arum spathe.
the titan arum
The citrus tree is infected by Candidatus Liberibacter causing citrus greening disease (huanglongbing).
The citrus leaf shows irregular blotchy mottle with yellow and green patches.
The infected citrus branch appears yellow when viewed from a distance.
The citrus twig shows dieback with dried and withered tips.
The citrus fruits are uneven in size, with many small fruits on the diseased tree.
The citrus fruit shows aborted seeds inside.
The vascular bundles in the fruit albedo are brown and discolored.
The citrus fruit shows color inversion with the stylar end remaining green.
The citrus fruit rind develops a grayish-white color when pressed.
The citrus fruit appears bitter and salty in flavor.
Citrus greening disease
In the daytime, Dendrosenecio kilimanjari has a stout upright woody stem with persistent leaf bases. In the daytime, Dendrosenecio kilimanjari has multiple branches.
In the daytime, each branch of Dendrosenecio kilimanjari ends with a giant terminal leaf rosette.
In the daytime, the overall appearance of Dendrosenecio kilimanjari, with its woody stem and crown of rosettes, makes the plant look like a giant pineapple.
In the daytime, the leaf rosettes of Dendrosenecio kilimanjari are fully open to capture sunlight.
In the daytime, the open rosettes of Dendrosenecio kilimanjari look like large green crowns at the tips of the branches.
At night, the woody stem and branches of Dendrosenecio kilimanjari remain visible in the dark.
At night, the terminal leaf rosettes of Dendrosenecio kilimanjari fold their long leaves inward and close tightly to conserve heat.
At night, the closed leaf rosettes of Dendrosenecio kilimanjari look like tight round heads at the stem and branch tips.
At night, the contrast between the dark closed rosettes and the open daytime rosettes shows the plant’s adaptation to freezing temperatures.
Dendrosenecio kilimanjari
The special mechanism of Mimosa pudica is that its leaves fold together when touched to protect themselves.
The compound leaves of Mimosa pudica are fully open and feathery.
The leaflets of Mimosa pudica fold inward after being touched.
The leaflets of Mimosa pudica are tightly closed together after folding.
The leaflets of Mimosa pudica reopen and spread outward again a few minutes later.
Mimosa pudica
Mimosa pudica after being touched
Stage 1: The Venus flytrap has a flat, heart-shaped green petiole.
Stage 1: The Venus flytrap has a pair of green lobes connected by a central midrib.
Stage 1: The inner surface of the lobes is red.
Stage 1: The edges of the lobes are fringed with stiff hair-like cilia.
Stage 1: The inner surface of each lobe has three thin trigger hairs.
Stage 1: The lobes of the trap are fully open in the resting state.
Stage 2: An insect lands on the open trap and touches one of the trigger hairs on the inner surface of the lobes.
Stage 2: The insect repeatedly touches the trigger hairs.
Stage 3: The lobes of the trap snap shut in 0.1 second after the trigger hairs are touched.
Stage 3: The meshed cilia interlock when the lobes close, preventing the insect from escaping.
Stage 4: The lobes of the trap tighten further within 12 hours.
Stage 4: Secretory glands on the lobes release digestive fluids onto the prey.
Stage 5: The prey gradually breaks down over a period of 12 hours to 5 days.
Stage 5: Nutrients from the digested prey remain visible inside the lobes.
Stage 6: The lobes of the trap reopen about one week later, after digestion is complete or if the prey has escaped.
Stages and timing of the Venus flytrap carnivory process
Stage 1 – Open trap
Nepenthes has a green climbing stem with sword-shaped leaves.
Each leaf extends into a tendril that ends in a globe- or tube-shaped pitcher.
The pitcher has a colourful slippery rim called the peristome.
A lid is located above the pitcher opening.
Stage 2 – Prey attraction
An insect is attracted to the colourful peristome.
The insect crawls on the slippery rim near the opening.
The insect loses its footing and falls into the pitcher fluid.
Stage 3 – Prey retention
The smooth waxy inner wall of the pitcher prevents the insect from climbing out.
The fluid inside the pitcher drowns the insect.
Stage 4 – Digestion and absorption
Digestive enzymes in the fluid break down the insect gradually.
Glands on the inner surface of the pitcher absorb nutrients from the digested insect.
Stage 5 – Trap variation
Nepenthes produces large lower pitchers on the ground and smaller upper pitchers hanging from climbing stems.
Nepenthes
Stage 1: Coprinus comatus appears as a small white egg-shaped body emerging from the soil.
Stage 2: The mushroom develops into a cylindrical young cap covered with shaggy white scales.
Stage 3: The cap expands into a bell shape while the shaggy scales remain visible.
Stage 4: The edge of the cap begins to turn black and dissolve into an inky liquid.
Stage 5: The cap gradually autodigests from the edge upward, dripping black liquid.
Stage 6: The cap completely dissolves, leaving only the stem standing.
Young C. comatus
This is the 'Shaggy Mane' mushroom in its inky phase.
Late stage deliquescence
Stage 1: A caterpillar lies partially buried in the soil, intact in appearance and without external stroma.
Stage 2: A single dark brown or yellowish stroma emerges from the caterpillar’s head.
Stage 3: The stroma elongates to several centimeters with a slender longitudinally ridged stipe and a distinct clavate or fusiform head.
Stage 4: The mature fruiting body stands fully developed above the soil while the mummified caterpillar remains below.
Ophiocordyceps sinensis
Without a host: Cuscuta chinensis germinates from seed as a thin yellow vine lacking leaves and roots.
Without a host: The seedling has only a few days of food reserves and then dies.
With a host: Cuscuta chinensis coils around the stems of a nearby plant and attaches using haustoria.
With a host: The vine twines extensively around the host, often enveloping it completely.
With a host: Dense clusters of small white to cream flowers appear on the parasitic stems.
Cuscuta chinensis
Stage 1: Cuscuta chinensis germinates from seed as a thin yellow seedling lacking leaves and roots.
Stage 2: The seedling survives only a few days on its own food reserves before needing a host.
Stage 3: The seedling finds a host plant and attaches using haustoria at the point of contact.
Stage 4: The stem below the first point of attachment dies, and the plant no longer connects to the soil.
Stage 5: The vine twines around the host stems, often enveloping them completely.
Stage 6: Dense clusters of small white to cream flowers appear on the parasitic stems.
Stage 7: The plant withers and dies after producing seeds, leaving the seeds to continue the next cycle.
Cuscuta chinensis
Floating leaves: Trapa natans has undivided floating leaves arranged in a rosette at the water’s surface.
Floating leaves: The floating leaves are ovoid or triangular in shape with saw-tooth edges.
Floating leaves: The floating leaves are 2–3 cm long and borne on inflated petioles 5–9 cm long, which provide buoyancy.
Submerged leaves: Trapa natans has finely divided, feather-like submerged leaves borne along the length of the stem.
Submerged leaves: The submerged stem can reach several metres in length and is anchored in the mud by very fine roots.
Water caltrop
Generate a four-panel image illustrating the morphological transition of Platycerium wallichii from shield fronds to antler-shaped fronds.
Stage 1 – Shield fronds
The basal fronds of Platycerium wallichii are sterile, rounded or kidney-shaped.
The basal fronds are laminate against the tree surface and protect the roots from damage and desiccation.
Stage 2 – Crown formation
The top margin of the basal fronds grows upward into an open crown of lobes.
The crown of basal fronds catches rainwater, forest litter, and animal droppings.
Stage 3 – Developing fertile fronds
The fertile fronds emerge from the rhizome and branch dichotomously.
The fertile fronds begin to extend outward or hang pendulously from the rhizome.
Stage 4 – Mature antler fronds with spores
The fertile fronds are fully antler-shaped with long lobes.
The undersides of fertile fronds bear clusters of spores.
The spores are arranged in large sori positioned at the tips of lobes, on stalked lobes, or at the sinus between frond lobes.
Stage 1 – Initial plant body
Lithops appears as a small stone-like succulent with two thick leaves fused together.
The leaves of Lithops are partially buried in the soil and flush with the ground surface.
The upper surface of the leaves shows stone-like colors and patterns.
Stage 2 – Fissure opening
The central fissure between the two leaves gradually widens. A small flower bud begins to emerge from the fissure.
Stage 3 – Flowering
A daisy-like flower with many narrow petals opens from the fissure.
The flower is yellow, pale orange, or white in color.
The flower opens in the afternoon and closes again in late afternoon.
Stage 4 – Fruiting
After the flower fades, a round fruit capsule remains in the fissure. The fruit capsule opens when wet and closes again when dry.
Stage 5 – New leaf growth
A new pair of leaves develops inside the fissure of the old leaves.
The new leaf pair pushes upward between the old leaves.
Stage 6 – Renewal and division
The old leaves shrivel and wither into a dry papery sheath beside the new body.
The plant may divide to produce two or more pairs of leaves, forming a small cluster.
Lithops  pseudotruncatella
Low light:
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa are larger and broader in low light.
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa are light green in low light.
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa have fewer fenestrations in low light.
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa appear more complete and heart-shaped or oval in low light.
Strong light:
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa are thicker and more rigid in strong light.
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa are dark green and glossy in strong light.
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa have more fenestrations in strong light.
The leaves of Monstera deliciosa show the typical split and perforated Monstera form in strong light.
Monstera deliciosa
Spring: The needle-like linear leaves are alternate, with entire margins, and appear light green.
Summer: The needle-like leaves are abundant, alternate, and deep green in color.
Autumn: The leaves turn bright yellow or copper red before falling.
Winter: The tree has bare branches with no leaves.
Foliage
Foliage in autumn
Sufficient nitrogen:
The corn plants are tall with a height of 2–3 meters.
The stems of the corn plants are thick and sturdy.
The leaves of the corn plants are dark green and broad.
The ears of the corn plants are full and well-developed with dense kernels.
Low nitrogen:
The corn plants are short with a height of less than 1 meter.
The stems of the corn plants are thin and weak.
The leaves of the corn plants are yellow, starting from the lower leaves.
The ears of the corn plants are small and short.
The kernels on the corn ears are sparse and irregular.
Many gaps are visible on the cob where kernels are missing.
Stage 1 – Seedling
A young strawberry seedling has thin stems with clusters of three serrated green leaflets.
Stage 2 – Root establishment
A strawberry plant grows low to the ground with dense clusters of bright green serrated leaves.
Early flowers are visible between the leaves.
Stage 3 – Vegetative growth
A strawberry plant has a wide low form with lush green trifoliate leaves.
Long slender runners extend along the ground with small plantlets at their tips.
Stage 4 – Flowering
White strawberry flowers with five petals and yellow centers stand above the foliage.
Numerous blossoms are visible on the plant.
Stage 5 – Fruiting
Small green strawberries are visible at the centers of the flowers.
Partially ripe strawberries are pink in color.
Ripe strawberries are red, heart-shaped, glossy, and covered in tiny surface seeds.
Stage 6 – Dormancy
A strawberry plant has bare crowns at the soil surface.
The plant has no green leaves above the ground.
The Queen of Tea Flowers refers to Camellia petelotii.
Camellia petelotii is a shrub.
Camellia petelotii grows 6 to 10 feet tall.
The leaves of Camellia petelotii are evergreen.
The leaves of Camellia petelotii are elliptic-oblong.
The leaves of Camellia petelotii are glossy.
The young leaves of Camellia petelotii are purple.
The mature leaves of Camellia petelotii are dark green.
The flowers of Camellia petelotii are solitary.
A shrub of Camellia petelotii bears multiple solitary flowers scattered on different branches.
The flowers of Camellia petelotii are golden yellow.
The flowers of Camellia petelotii are about 2 inches across.
The flowers of Camellia petelotii have 8 to 12 petals.
The stamens of Camellia petelotii are yellow and bushy.
Camellia petelotii
During the flowering period, Cereus forbesii has tall, columnar green stems with spines along the ribs.
Large funnel-shaped flowers appear singly on the stems.
At night:
The flowers of Cereus forbesii are fully open.
The flowers are large.
The flowers are funnel-shaped.
The flowers are white to reddish.
The outer petals have pink backs.
The flower centers are bright yellow.
During the day:
The flowers of Cereus forbesii are closed.
The closed flowers are folded.
The flowers remain attached to the columnar stems.
Cereus forbesii flower
The sepals of ‘Blaze’ are bright red.
The petals of ‘Blaze’ are vibrant pink.
The sepals of ‘Comet’ are white.
The petals of ‘Comet’ are tender pink.
Stage 1 – Seedling:
A small seedling emerges from the soil with two cotyledons.
Tiny green true leaves begin to develop.
Stage 2 – Vine growth:
Long sprawling green vines extend across the ground.
The lobed true leaves spread widely along the vines.
Stage 3 – Flowering and pollination:
Yellow male and female flowers bloom along the vines.
Male flowers are more numerous, while female flowers have a small ovary beneath the petals.
Insects pollinate the flowers.
Stage 4 – Fruit initiation:
Small round green fruits appear behind the female flowers.
The young fruits are smooth and dark green.
Stage 5 – Fruit enlargement:
The fruits grow larger, round to oblong in shape.
The rind develops dark green stripes on a lighter green background.
Stage 6 – Maturity and harvest:
The watermelon reaches full size, large and heavy.
The rind has distinct striping, and the inside is red with black seeds (shown in a cross-section).
At this stage, the fruit is harvested.
Stage 7 – Post-harvest drying:
The vine dries out after fruit harvest.
New seeds from the ripe watermelon can be replanted to restart the cycle.
watermelon

Germination & Sprouting
Hevea brasiliensis (rubber tree) secretes white latex when wounded.
The tree can grow up to 43 meters tall in the wild.
The trunk is cylindrical.
The trunk may have a swollen, bottle-shaped base.
The bark is brown.
The leaves have three leaflets.
The leaves are spirally arranged.
Hevea brasiliensis
Panel 1 – Nocturnal flowering
The bat-pollinated flower opens at night.
The flower is large, pale-colored, and tubular or bell-shaped.
The background is a dark night sky.
Panel 2 – Bat approaches
A bat flies toward the flower guided by scent and echolocation.
The flower emits visible odor lines to indicate fragrance.
The flower is positioned away from foliage for easy access.
Panel 3 – Feeding and pollen attachment
The bat hovers in front of the flower and inserts its head inside.
The bat’s fur and face contact the anthers.
Yellow pollen grains attach to the bat’s head and snout.
Panel 4 – Cross-pollination
The bat visits another flower on a nearby branch.
The pollen on its face touches the stigma of the new flower.
Panel 1 – Early stage (Primary succession)
The ground is barren volcanic lava or ash with no soil.
Pioneer mosses, lichens, and hardy grasses colonize the rocky surface.
The soil layer is extremely thin and nutrient-poor.
Panel 2 – Intermediate stage
The soil becomes thicker and more fertile.
Herbaceous plants and small shrubs establish.
Nitrogen-fixing plants appear and enrich the soil.
Roots stabilize the soil and create improved microenvironments.
Panel 3 – Late stage (Climax community)
Woody plants and trees gradually dominate.
Dense layers of shrubs, trees, and understory plants form.
Plant diversity and biomass increase significantly, developing into a forest community.
Emergent layer
The tallest trees rise above the canopy.
Crowns are umbrella-shaped and widely spaced.
Canopy layer
A dense, continuous green roof of interlocking crowns.
Epiphytes and lianas are abundant on branches and trunks.
The canopy is sunlit and wind-exposed.
Understory layer
Smaller shade-tolerant trees form a lower, broken ceiling.
Leaves are broad and thin to capture limited light.
The understory is dim and humid.
Shrub / sapling layer
Shrubs and young trees occupy the space near the ground.
Stems are slender with sparse, shade-adapted foliage.
Forest floor
The ground is dark with scattered shade plants.
Tree trunks, fallen leaves, and decomposing litter are prominent.
Fungi and decomposers spread across damp soil.
the vertical stratification of vegetation in a tropical rainforest
Panel 1 – Mycelium colonization
White mycelium spreads as fine, cotton-like threads inside and across the surface of the decaying hardwood.
The wood surface looks moist and partially decomposed.
Moss grows around the log.
Fallen leaves lie scattered on the damp soil.
A faint mist lingers near the ground.
Panel 2 – Primordia formation
Small pinhead-sized bumps appear on the moist wood surface.
The primordia are tiny and round in shape.
The primordia are light brown in color.
The primordia have a moist and slightly translucent texture.
Several primordia are at different sizes, showing uneven development.
Panel 3 – Fruiting body development
The primordia expand into kidney-shaped or fan-shaped caps with side-attached stems.
The caps are reddish-brown in color.
The cap surfaces are shiny with a varnished appearance.
The cap edges are slightly curved, showing they are still growing.
Panel 4 – Maturation
The cap is fully expanded into a broad fan-like form.
The cap is deep reddish-brown in color.
The cap surface shows clear concentric bands.
The underside has fine yellowish pores.
Yellow spores are released as a light powdery cloud.
wild Lingzhi mushroom
The Grass-of-Parnassus was the county flower of Cumberland in England.
The plant grows as a clump with a basal rosette of leaves.
The basal leaves are heart-shaped and lie close to the ground.
The basal leaves are smooth and medium green.
Flowering stems rise independently from the base and are leafless.
Each flowering stem bears a solitary white flower at the top.
The flowers have five white petals with translucent green veins.
The flower center has five stamens with yellow anthers.
Small nectar scales are present around the stamens.
The flower diameter is similar to or slightly smaller than the width of one leaf.
The stems are slender, upright, and green.
The background shows moist grassland with moss patches.
Parnassia palustris
Parnassia palustris-flower
The Bee Orchid, Ophrys apifera, was the county flower of Bedfordshire in England.
The plant grows to a height of 15–50 cm.
It develops a small basal rosette of ovate or oblong-lanceolate leaves.
The basal leaves are green with parallel venation.
The upper leaves and bracts are ovate-lanceolate and sheathing.
A flower spike bears one to twelve flowers.
Each flower has three large purple sepals that look like petals.
Above the sepals are two short, pubescent green true petals.
The central column is a fused structure of stamens and pistil.
The anther cap is visible at the top of the column.
Two pollinia hang from the column over the labellum.
The labellum is a modified petal at the bottom of the column.
The labellum is trilobed with hairy lateral lobes forming two humps.
The median lobe of the labellum is hairy and patterned to mimic a bee’s abdomen.
The Bee Orchid
The Loddon Lily, Leucojum aestivum, was the county flower of Berkshire in England.
The plant is a perennial bulbous species, 35–60 cm tall, sometimes reaching 90 cm.
The leaves are strap-shaped, 5–20 mm wide, and grow to the same height as the flowers.
The leaves are green, smooth, and narrow.
The flowering stem is hollow with translucent winged margins.
Each stem bears an umbel of three to five pendant flowers, sometimes up to seven.
The flower stalks are slender and of unequal length.
Each flower is bell-shaped and about 3–4 cm in diameter.
The flowers have six white tepals of equal length.
Each tepal has a green mark just below its tip.
Leucojum aestivum
The German gentian, Gentianella germanica, was the county flower of Buckinghamshire in England.
The plant is an annual or biennial species, 5 to 40 cm tall.
The stems are mostly unbranched or with very few branches.
When biennial, the first year produces a basal rosette of leaves, which wither before flowering.
The stem leaves are opposite, deep green, and taper to a sharp point.
The leaf shape varies from ovate to ovate-lanceolate or ovate-triangular.
The flowers grow singly from the axils of the leaves.
The flowers are funnel-shaped and usually reddish-violet, though occasionally white.
Each flower is about 3.5 cm long.
The sepals are partly fused at the base, dividing into five pointed lobes.
The corolla tube divides into five pointed petal lobes, sometimes only four.
The petal lobes are up to 15 mm long with slightly rough edges.
Inside the floral tube, a ring of long hairs is visible.
Each flower has five stamens and two stigmas in the throat.
A single plant can produce from 4 to over 40 flowers during the season.
Gentianella germanica
